What we're following at a glance

Updated 17 October 2025, 14:30

Live
  • Regional Summit:

    Leaders from across the Adriatic region gathered in Split for emergency talks on maritime security. The meeting, which lasted well into the evening, addressed growing concerns about shipping lane disruptions and the need for coordinated naval patrols. Participants agreed to establish a joint task force, though specific implementation details remain under negotiation. The summit marks the first major diplomatic initiative since tensions escalated last month.

  • Economic Forecast:

    The latest quarterly report from the European Central Bank suggests a modest economic recovery across southeastern Europe, with GDP growth projected at 2.3% for the coming year. Analysts attribute the optimistic outlook to increased foreign investment and stabilizing energy prices. However, concerns remain about persistent inflation in consumer goods and the long-term sustainability of current fiscal policies. Trade organizations have called for additional structural reforms to support small businesses.

  • Cultural Heritage:

    UNESCO has announced the addition of three Adriatic coastal sites to its World Heritage List, recognizing their historical significance and architectural uniqueness. The designations are expected to boost tourism revenue but also impose stricter preservation requirements on local governments. Conservationists praised the decision as crucial for protecting threatened archaeological sites from urban development pressures. Local communities have expressed mixed reactions, balancing economic opportunities with concerns about increased visitor traffic.

Trump rebuked

Populist moment denied

Nicușor Dan’s surprise win over far-right firebrand George Simion in Romania’s presidential runoff marks a high-turnout rejection of “Romania First” populism — and signals a broader regional pushback as the EU’s eastern flank faces mounting democratic pressure.

Maja Dragović
Same as the old

The long march to Europe

Albania’s ruling Socialist Party has secured a fourth consecutive term for Prime Minister Edi Rama, extending his reign as the longest-serving leader of the country’s post-communist era.
